docs.abstract: For more than four decades, Robert Adams’s landscape photographs have reminded us of what has been lost in America, and what endures.
docs.snippet: For more than four decades, Robert Adams’s landscape photographs have reminded us of what has been lost in America, and what endures.
docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Adams’s succinct preface to his 2010 book of photographs “What Can We Believe Where?” begins with uplift: “In common with many photographers,” he writes, “I began making pictures because I wanted to record what supports hope: the untranslatable mystery and beauty of the world.” Adams’s aim was true. Look at one of his photographs and you’ll see a record of mystery and beauty. The photographic elements are simple. Bright sunlight, generally; crisp shadow; the occasional moody nocturne. We feel as if we are being taught to see with a visual primer. Better yet, turn the pages of one of his books (he has made more than 50) or walk around an exhibition of his work, inhabiting the flow of his decisions. You are likely to feel your breath getting calmer and your senses quietened.

docs.abstract: Don’t turn the conversation to yourself. Offer support. Find out if it’s O.K. to tell others.
docs.snippet: Don’t turn the conversation to yourself. Offer support. Find out if it’s O.K. to tell others.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Remember that it’s not about you,” says Telaina Eriksen, a creative-writing professor at Michigan State University in East Lansing, who wrote a book about her daughter’s coming out as a lesbian. No matter what kind of relationship you have with the person, don’t immediately turn the conversation to yourself by saying something like “I knew it all along!” or “How could you do this to me?” If you are in a position of authority — a parent, teacher or coach — be extra careful; what you say will be imbued with that power differential. “Whatever you do,” Eriksen says, “don’t say, ‘Are you sure?’ ”

headline.main: How to Respond When Someone Comes Out to You
headline.print_headline: How to Respond When Someone Comes Out to You

docs.abstract: What is a team owner to do under pressure from the president of the United States?
docs.snippet: What is a team owner to do under pressure from the president of the United States?
docs.lead_paragraph: This was not your usual Super Bowl mob scene. It might have looked like it at first, on what the National Football League calls opening night, when it kicks off the holiest week of its year. The annual event has metastasized into a sprawling tumor of reporters yelling out questions — whether the Atlanta Falcons running back Devonta Freeman has a favorite fish (yes: tilapia), whether the New England Patriots center David Andrews has a favorite breakfast cereal (yes: Cap’n Crunch, Crunch Berries) and whether the Patriots coach Bill Belichick knows about “Bill Belichick Underwear,” a pair of which one TV reporter from Alaska claimed to be wearing (no: “Guess I missed that one,” Coach mumbled).

headline.main: The N.F.L. Stiff-Armed Trump. Now He Is Heckling From the White House.

docs.abstract: It didn’t hurt, but the woman wasn’t sure whether the streak on her arm was harmless or potentially dangerous.
docs.snippet: It didn’t hurt, but the woman wasn’t sure whether the streak on her arm was harmless or potentially dangerous.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Wow! What’s that on your arm?” a young dancer exclaimed in alarm. The 41-year-old dancer and choreographer looked at the part of her arm the other dancer was pointing to. A bright red line snaked down the side of her forearm, from wrist to elbow. She’d been completely unaware of it; it didn’t hurt or itch, so she dismissed it. For the past several days, they’d been rehearsing in an old barn in Martha’s Vineyard converted into a performance space. Maybe she’d scraped it on something. In any case, she didn’t have time to worry about it, she told her friend. They had only four days until they were supposed to perform this piece.

headline.main: She Had a Long and Strange Rash on Her Arm. What Was It?

docs.abstract: From HBO to ‘Star Wars’ to Shakspeare, he has discovered how to excel beyond tidy genres.
docs.snippet: From HBO to ‘Star Wars’ to Shakspeare, he has discovered how to excel beyond tidy genres.

docs.abstract: Considering the future with the retiring congressman Frank LoBiondo down the Jersey Shore.
docs.snippet: Considering the future with the retiring congressman Frank LoBiondo down the Jersey Shore.
docs.lead_paragraph: Early Wednesday, on the morning after Democrats swept the house and a few hours before President Trump fired Attorney General Jeff Sessions, I drove up from Washington to South Jersey to see a congressman named Frank LoBiondo. After 24 years in Congress, LoBiondo was trying to get his big oval noggin around the idea of retirement.

headline.main: A Pre-Trump Republican Rides the Blue Wave Out to Sea

docs.abstract: New research is zeroing in on a biochemical basis for the placebo effect — possibly opening a Pandora’s box for Western medicine.
docs.snippet: New research is zeroing in on a biochemical basis for the placebo effect — possibly opening a Pandora’s box for Western medicine.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Chain of Office of the Dutch city of Leiden is a broad and colorful ceremonial necklace that, draped around the shoulders of Mayor Henri Lenferink, lends a magisterial air to official proceedings in this ancient university town. But whatever gravitas it provided Lenferink as he welcomed a group of researchers to his city, he was quick to undercut it. “I am just a humble historian,” he told the 300 members of the Society for Interdisciplinary Placebo Studies who had gathered in Leiden’s ornate municipal concert hall, “so I don’t know anything about your topic.” He was being a little disingenuous. He knew enough about the topic that these psychologists and neuroscientists and physicians and anthropologists and philosophers had come to his city to talk about — the placebo effect, the phenomenon whereby suffering people get better from treatments that have no discernible reason to work — to call it “fake medicine,” and to add that it probably works because “people like to be cheated.” He took a beat. “But in the end, I believe that honesty will prevail.”

headline.main: What if the Placebo Effect Isn’t a Trick?

docs.abstract: It’s difficult to relate to history when the moments of now are persistently swarming us.

docs.abstract: Surely we can do better than “hair soap.”
docs.snippet: Surely we can do better than “hair soap.”
docs.lead_paragraph: Adam writes: My weird nieces insist on calling shampoo “hair soap.” They further insist that a close relative or family friend taught them this phrasing, but I suspect they are lying. Please order them to call shampoo by its proper name.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on a New Name for Shampoo
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: After years of misdiagnoses, Stephen Hopkins learned that lead in his bones was making him sick. Now he’s calling for the military to increase testing for metal poisoning in troops.
docs.snippet: After years of misdiagnoses, Stephen Hopkins learned that lead in his bones was making him sick. Now he’s calling for the military to increase testing for metal poisoning in troops.
docs.lead_paragraph: At age 30, Stephen Hopkins was back in the Army for a second time. After serving as an enlisted soldier from 1991 to 1995, he returned as an officer in 2000. He was a man who routinely maxed fitness tests and endured physical hardship while deployed to rural locales in Afghanistan. Selected for Special Forces training, Hopkins tackled the demanding courses with gusto, later returning to combat for a total of seven deployments. He had a job he loved and excelled at, and his star was ascending.

headline.main: The Army Thought He Was Faking His Health Issues. Turns Out He Had Chronic Lead Poisoning.
